subject: Add support for the BootSourceOverrideMode
commitMessage:
Add support for the BootSourceOverrideMode

BootSourceOverrideMode is the BIOS boot mode to use when
the system boots from the BootSourceOverrideTarget boot source.

Possible values are:
-Legacy - The system boots in non-UEFI boot mode to
          the boot source override target
-UEFI   - The system boots in UEFI boot mode to
          the boot source override target

For the architectures that don't implement Legacy/UEFI boot mode
property (for example POWER), don't publish BootSourceOverrideMode
interface at all.

Redfish validator has been executed on this change and no new
error was found.

Also tested with the help of the openbmc-test-automation framework.
When the Legacy/UEFI boot mode is present in the system command for
testing is:
  robot -v PLATFORM_ARCH_TYPE:x86 \
        -v OPENBMC_HOST:<BMC IP> \
        redfish/systems/test_boot_devices.robot

When the Legacy/UEFI boot mode is not present in the system command
for testing is:
  robot -v OPENBMC_HOST:<BMC IP> \
        redfish/systems/test_boot_devices.robot

Signed-off-by: Konstantin Aladyshev <aladyshev22@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Id64e428752b820d481ce15d56566dd7b06738ec0

Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as cd9a4666e67563bad804d08b891f7d852ac6e18a by Ed Tanous
Please provide a "Testing" section where you lists tests you ran and confirm redfish validator has passed.

undefined behavior.  std::optional might not be populated.

You need to handle the case where bootType wasn't provided by the user.

Based on its use, I suspect you can do that in the higher level code, and simply declare this const std::string&, but I'm not positive on that.
Only call this if bootType is value? The function does not seem to handle the situation where this is invalid.
invert this check, and make it call internalError if it's empty.
Done
Aren't these overriding what the user has set?  If we have a different setting than the user has request, should we send an error?

If the `BootSourceOverrideEnabled` option is provided, we use it to deduce what interface we should update:
- "Once" => /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/one_time
- "Continuous" => /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot     [=persistent boot]
- "Disabled" => nothing
Also we update '/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/one_time' `Enabled` property based on the user choise.

If the `BootSourceOverrideEnabled` option is not provided, we update the current enabled interface. The decision is made based on the /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/one_time Enabled property:
- if Enabled==false, then we update /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/    
- if Enabled==true, then we update /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/one_time

> If the `BootSourceOverrideEnabled` option is provided, we use it to deduce what interface we should update:
> - "Once" => /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/one_time
> - "Continuous" => /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot     [=persistent boot]
> - "Disabled" => nothing
> Also we update '/xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/one_time' `Enabled` property based on the user choise.
> 
> If the `BootSourceOverrideEnabled` option is not provided, we update the current enabled interface. The decision is made based on the /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/one_time Enabled property:
> - if Enabled==false, then we update /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/    
> - if Enabled==true, then we update /xyz/openbmc_project/control/host0/boot/one_time

I read this patchset wrong.  I thought oneTimeSetting had come from the user on this request, not from dbus.  Fine as-is.
typically don't use auto here

It comes from the rfMode/rfSource code, you can see in other parts of the file:
```
auto rfMode = dbusToRfBootMode(*bootModeStr);
auto rfSource = dbusToRfBootSource(*bootSourceStr);
```
In this case I should correct them too.
Could you please explain, why `std::string` is preferrable to `auto` in this case?

Need messages::success(aResp->res); here?

https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/40969

I've tried to add it, but it doesn't change the response code for the PATCH message, code remains 204 (No Content).

Tested with:
```
$ python redfishtool.py -r <IP> -u root -p 0penBmc -S Always Systems setBootOverride Continuous None -sss

...
#REQUEST:  PATCH     https://<IP>/redfish/v1/Systems/system
#__Request.Headers:  {'User-Agent': 'python-requests/2.25.1', 'Accept': 'application/json', 'Connection': 'keep-alive', 'OData-Version': '4.0', 'Content-Type': 'application/json', 'Content-Length': '89', 'Authorization': 'Basic cm9vdDowcGVuQm1j'}
#__Request AuthType: Basic
#__Request Data: {"Boot": {"BootSourceOverrideEnabled": "Continuous", "BootSourceOverrideTarget": "None"}}
#__Response.status_code: 204,         r.url: https://<IP>/redfish/v1/Systems/system
#__Response.elapsed(responseTime): 0.18 sec
...
```

However if I add `messages::internalError(aResp->res);` here responce code changes to 500.

Am I missing something?
operator[] creates the key if it doesn't exist.  This is almost certainly not the behavior you want.  Use find.

Now when we use chain "BootSource->BootMode->BootType"
This would be always created in "dbusToRfBootSource" function
common error #12.

Isn't it a percise matching?
Or am I looking at the wrong API:
https://json.nlohmann.me/api/basic_json/contains/
This is all asynch stuff, are we really guaranteed that getBootType() has completed by the time we get here?
+1.  This is an instance of common error #7.

How should I handle this check in this case?
Can you provide me some help of how I should resolve this problem.
If both are really needed then you'll need to embed the asynch call within the other asynch call and execute this logic in the callback at the bottom of the stack that has both variables figured out.

If it is needed to be done the check above also has this mistake. I mean:
```
if (aResp->res.jsonValue["Boot"]["BootSourceOverrideTarget"] == "None"
```
Because this code checks against "None" value which can be obtained only from the `dbusToRfBootSource` function which is executed in a separate async call for the Dbus "xyz.openbmc_project.Control.Boot.Source" interface.

In this case it seems like all the calls should be chainloaded:
```
BootSource->BootMode->BootType
```
_____________

This is the example of the flaws in a current OpenBMC boot override design that I've tried to highlight recently in a Discord.
Because there is no Enable/Disable flag for the boot override object on a Dbus, bmcweb and phosphor-ipmid have to do weird stuff like this. And they solve this problem in a separate ways: (speaking in terms of bmcweb)

bmcweb:
```
"BootSourceOverrideEnabled=Disabled" = "BootSourceOverrideMode=UEFI" + "BootSourceOverrideTarget=None"
```
ipmid:
```
"BootSourceOverrideEnabled" can't be "Disabled", it is always "Once" or "Continuous"
```
Done
?  If the mode isn't UEFI, we completely ignore the param?  That doesn't seem right at all.

This part of code is trying to describe "BootSourceOverrideEnabled=Disabled" state.
Currently there is no interface in the Settings object that can provide such functionality.
So the code that was here before used a logic that if the "BootSourceOverrideTarget" equals "None" (=is in the default state) then "BootSourceOverrideEnabled" should be reported as "Disabled".
If we add Legacy/EFI selector to this context, we can report "BootSourceOverrideTarget=Disabled" only when both "BootSourceOverrideTarget=None" and "BootSourceOverrideMode=UEFI" (as it is our new default state).
+1.  Common error #11.
Done
See below, but it's odd to me we'd have any "default" here on set.

This is one more hack that goes from the limitations of the current implementation of Boot Override feature in OpenBMC (see https://lists.ozlabs.org/pipermail/openbmc/2021-May/026533.html).
The main problem is a fact that we don't have any `enabled` property for the Dbus Boot settings override.
Therefore if we have received "BootSourceOverrideEnabled=Disabled", the only 'sane' thing that we can do is to set BootSource/BootMode/BootType to their default values.

You can look at the `setBootModeOrSource` function that wasn't changed in this commit, it uses the same principle.
```
    std::string bootSourceStr =
        "xyz.openbmc_project.Control.Boot.Source.Sources.Default";
    std::string bootModeStr =
        "xyz.openbmc_project.Control.Boot.Mode.Modes.Regular";
```
Doesn't this need to be within the if(bootType) check?  If the user hasn't requested anything (either explicitly or implicitly), we shouldn't be changing the setting.

We need to try to do this in a current design.
For example if a user only have requested "BootSourceOverrideEnabled=Disabled", we need to set all the parameters to their default values:
```
BootSource = Default
BootMode = Regular
BootType = EFI
```

Does this need to be set before the boot type/boot mode?  (not sure here).

Also, this should be in its own method, similar to setBootType
I don't think that there should be any strict order, I think they can be set independently.
Moved the code to a separate method.
